citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A written program of veterinary care was not available for review at the time of inspection. A written program of veterinary
care is needed to establish an adequate standard of care for the animals on hand. Each dealer shall employ an attending
veterinarian under formal arrangements, and in the case of a part-time attending veterinarian or consultant arrangements,
the formal arrangements shall include a written program of veterinary care and regularly scheduled visits to the premises.
To be corrected by September 30, 2025

Disposition records for the sale of 1 baby capuchin and 1 baby spider monkey were not available at the time of inspection.
Failure to provide this information may interfere with the ability of APHIS officials to identify animals and to trace their
movements. Each dealer shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the required
information concerning each animal purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, or otherwise in his or her possession
or under his or her control, or which is transported, euthanized, sold, or otherwise disposed of.
To be corrected by September 30, 2025

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, there was no documented program of environmental enhancement available for review, for the
non-human primates housed at the facility. An adequate environmental enhancement program is essential in promoting
the psychological well-being of non-human primates. Dealers, exhibitors, and research facilities must develop, document,
and follow an appropriate plan for environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of non-
human primates. This plan must be made available to APHIS upon request.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.40(a)(1) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A written program of veterinary care was not available for review at the time of inspection. A written program of veterinary 
care is needed to establish an adequate standard of care for the animals on hand. Each dealer shall employ an attending 
veterinarian under formal arrangements, and in the case of a part-time attending veterinarian or consultant arrangements, 
the formal arrangements shall include a written program of veterinary care and regularly scheduled visits to the premises.  
To be corrected by September 30, 2025 
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
Disposition records for the sale of 1 baby capuchin and 1 baby spider monkey were not available at the time of inspection. 
Failure to provide this information may interfere with the ability of APHIS officials to identify animals and to trace their 
movements. Each dealer shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the required 
information concerning each animal purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, or otherwise in his or her possession 
or under his or her control, or which is transported, euthanized, sold, or otherwise disposed of.  
To be corrected by September 30, 2025 
3.81  Repeat
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
At the time of inspection, there was no documented program of environmental enhancement available for review, for the 
non-human primates housed at the facility. An adequate environmental enhancement program is essential in promoting 
the psychological well-being of non-human primates. Dealers, exhibitors, and research facilities must develop, document, 
and follow an appropriate plan for environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of non-
human primates. This plan must be made available to APHIS upon request. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
